content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>U.S. Geological Survey </origin> <pubdate>2003 </pubdate> <title>Seagrass Presence Structures Densities and Distributions of Two Estuarine Gobies: laboratory and field evidence </title> <geoform>poster </geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Gainesville, FL </pubplace> <publish>USGS </publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://cars.er.usgs.gov/posters/Coastal_Ecology/Goby_and_Seagrass_Beds/goby_and_seagrass_beds.html </onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>Densities of the code goby Gobiosoma robustum Ginsburg and clown goby Microgobius gulosus (Girard) vary across regions of Florida Bay. Although their distributions overlap to a limited degree, G. robustum is found in great abundance in the seagrass beds of the western and southern portion of the bay, where a strong Gulf of Mexico influence maintains salinities at a relatively constant level (35-40 ppt). Conversely, M. gulosus is most common in the north-eastern section of the bay that is influenced by freshwater inflow and generally is characterised by lower salinities and sparse submerged vegetation. </abstract> <purpose>To examine the effects of salinity, habitat complexity, competition, and susceptibility to predation as possible factors underlying the distribution of these two species. </purpose> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>2001 </caldate> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <current>ground condition </current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete </progress>
